question:
Find the interval and radius of convergence of the series
 $$sum_{{n=0}}^{{\infty}}(-1)^{{n}}$$ $$\frac{{x^{{2 n}}}}{{(2 n) !}}$$
answer:
The procedure is as follows
Since $\left |(-1)^{{n}} \right| = \left|(-1)^{{n+1}}\right| = 1$, we have 
$k=\operatorname{{Lim}}_{{n \rightarrow \infty}}\left|\frac{{a_{{n+1}}}}{{a_{{n}}}}\right|<1 which yields
$$\begin{{aligned}}
k=\lim_{{n \rightarrow \infty}}\left|\frac{{x^{{2(n+1)}}}}{{[2(n+1)] !}} \cdot \frac{{(2 n) !}}{{x^{{2 n}}}}\right|<1 
k=\operatorname{{Lim}}_{{n \rightarrow \infty}}\left|\frac{{x^{{2 n+2}}}}{{x^{{2 n}}}}-\frac{{(2 n) !}}{{(2 n+2) !}}\right|<1 
\end{{aligned}}$$
$$\begin{{aligned}}
k=\operatorname{{Lim}}_{{n \rightarrow \infty}}\left[\frac{{x^{{n+1}}}}{{x^{{n}}}} \cdot \frac{{n !}}{{(n+1) !}}\right]<1 \text {{ yields }} 
\text {{ from simplifying }} \frac{{x^{{n+1}}}}{{x^{{n}}}}=x^{{\not+1=x}}=x 
\text {{ and }} \frac{{n !}}{{(n+1) !}}=\frac{{n !}}{{(n+1) n !}}=\frac{{1}}{{n+1}} 
k=\operatorname{{Lim}}_{{n \rightarrow \infty}}\left|\frac{{x}}{{n+1}}\right|<1 \text {{ as }} n \text {{ approach }} \infty 
k=\frac{{1}}{{\infty+1}} \cdot x \Rightarrow k=\frac{{1}}{{\infty}} \cdot x \Rightarrow k=0 \cdot x=0 
\end{{aligned}}$$
Since $k<1$ for all $x$, the series converge absolutely for all $x$.
Thus, the interval of convergence is $(-\infty,+\infty)$ and the radius of convergence is $R=+\infty$

question: Find the solution to the following integral $$\int_{{0}}^{{1}}x^2$$
answer:
The procedure is as follows
The integral of $x^2$ is $\frac{{x^3}}{{3}}$
Using the upper and lower bound gives $\frac{{1^3}}{{3}} - \frac{{0^3}}{{3}}$
The final answer is $\frac{{1}}{{3}}$
